content.description: Start at the slabby bulge that is covered in lichen and go straight up on good feet to jugs. Continue up and trend right to a horizontal finger crack at the roof. Pull the easy roof carefully so as not to knock rocks loose and squirm between trees, branches and brush in a dirtfest topout to a mondo tree.
content.protection: Standard Rack, takes things on the smaller end of the standard rack with a bomb nut in the finger crack before you pull the roof.
content.location: Located to the left and up the hill from the Upper Cascades trail. Turn left when you see the huge cave and go up the hill.

content.description: Start out on steep ground into an easy ravine until you reach a small, green roof. traverse out right a couple feet for better positioning and then awkwardly work your way left on slippery crimps until you can reach the anchor tree.
content.protection: A couple cams for the roof traverse, the first part can probably take a small piece or two if you really wanted to. A standard size sling is not quite big enough for a good anchor on the tree.
content.location: Right of Not Lichen It Lovin It closer to the big cave. There's a small tree at the base, look for the obvious ravine with a shrub or two in it.

content.description:
Short climb starting in a bit of a dihedral, interesting but easy moves leading to a 4th class finish and a mondo tree. 

  Top rope can be set by walking up around to the right of the cliff.
content.protection: Standard Rack, takes many different placements.

content.description:
This cliff looks like it has potential for some pretty hard trad routes namely involving the huge cave and the roof at the top. There are also a bunch of easy looking lines.  

  As of 10/2016, this area is very dirty. Spider webs and lichen dominate the rock and rocks getting knocked loose is definitely a danger. 

  P.S. If any information here is inaccurate and you know something more, feel free to let me know. As of right now all route information is being made up as it happens and first ascents are my best guess. Cheers
